stem: A 45-year-old client is 6 hours post-subtotal thyroidectomy for Graves' disease. Based on the documentation in the Post-Thyroidectomy Surgical & Electrolyte Surveillance tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hypermetabolic state post-neck surgery.
Background: Pre-op treatment with Lugol's solution. Difficulty during surgical gland manipulation.
Assessment: Client is extremely agitated, reporting a 'racing' feeling. Temperature is spiking.
Recommendation: Beta-blockade and calcium check.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Propranolol to inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3
Provide cooling blankets and acetaminophen to treat hyperpyrexia
Encourage the client to move their neck frequently to prevent stiffness

parameterOptions.text: Continuous Heart Rate and Core Temperature monitoring
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Post-Surgical Thyroid Storm (c2), caused by the 'dumping' of thyroid hormone into the bloodstream during surgical manipulation of the gland. Hallmark signs are the 4 T's: Temperature (104.2), Tachycardia (162), Tremor/Agitation, and Toxicity. Priority actions are blocking the hormone effect with Propranolol (a1) and managing the lethal fever (a2). A critical dual-parameter is monitoring for hypocalcemia (p2), as thyroid surgery often accidentally damages the parathyroids, which could cause a second crisis (tetany) shortly after the storm.
clinicalPearls: Thyroid storm post-op is an EMERGENCY because it can lead to acute heart failure.
Propranolol is preferred over other beta-blockers because it also stops T4 from turning into the more potent T3.
Aspirin is CONTRAINDICATED in thyroid storm because it displaces thyroid hormone from carrier proteins, making the storm worse.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never give Aspirin for thyroid storm. Use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) instead. Aspirin 'unsticks' thyroid hormone into the blood, fueling the fire.
